Come see me Witch it up in Hansel & Gretel!

Hansel & Gretel

Sunday August 2, 2009 - 2:00 PM
OPERA DEL WEST presents Hänsel und Gretel
 
Much admired for its folk music-inspired themes, Hänsel und Gretel is an opera by nineteenth-century composer Engelbert Humberdinck (the one born in 1854) who described it as a Marchenoper (fairy tale opera). In 1947, Hansel und Gretel was the first Metropolitan Opera performance heard on radio, and later became the Met’s first complete recording in English issued by Columbia Masterworks Records in 1947. By no means a children’s opera, but one for music lovers of all ages to enjoy!
Admission: $18 members $16
Students/Seniors $1 discount

www.natickarts.org

Wednesday

 

Didn’t have rehearsal until late, so I got to sleep in a little. Man, I don’t think I’ve ever slept so well...it rained here and I always sleep so well when it rains in Vermont. Just something about the air and the sound of rain. I love it. Though, I could do without the cold. I don’t know what I’m going to do when I have to go back to sleeping only a few hours a night. That’s going to suck.

 

They were running really late during rehearsal which was kind of good as I was able to check e-mail and got the good news about being cast in Hansel & Gretel. YAY! It’s gonna be nuts for me to try and get all of this learned, but I’ll figure something out. First I need to get the score here somehow...

 

My aria went much better today. Thank god. I’ve come to understand the conductor a little better and the director as well. The director could see that I’ve put a lot of thought into it and he was happy with the progress that we are making... phew!

 

We watched the Met’s broadcast of “The Audition” which was actually even better the second time around. I feel so nervous for all of those people. It’s soooooo scary being in that sort of situation without cameras everywhere, nevermind with them! Sheesh! I can’t imagine what kind of pressure they were all feeling with the cameras everywhere... I’m glad that it was done though. It really gives us all some perspective (even though we know it is all fixed...kinda). The sweetest thing was when all of us Il Barbiere singers walked into the theater, the audience clapped. Our director announced that the reason people were clapping (in case they didn’t know) was that the singers from the show were in the audience and he acknowledged all of us. It was very sweet and really cool. The community here is soooo supportive and very very arts-oriented. It is so refreshing to see. Another interesting thing - one of the finalists in the met competition sang the Witch’s aria from Hansel & Gretel. It is sort of an odd aria, but rather difficult. I found it odd that she would choose that aria(or that they would). But I guess it is something a little different, and they do perform that opera at the met...so it kind of makes sense???

 

Thursday

 

No rehearsal today until 6:00pm. YAY! Our conductor is away for a few days which is a welcome respite. He is very kind and I like him a great deal, but it is still weird living with you conductor no matter how you look at it! Meredith and I went out for brunch while the cleaning lady was here and we spent the rest of the time resting as she has not had any chance to rest at all. I’ve been catching up on some reading, which I never get to do, and listening to the Witch’s role in Hansel & Gretel. It is sort of crazy and I’m trying not to over-think things. Like how the hell can I learn this challenging music so quickly? But then I remember that I learned Silla in 4 days with no previous recordings to listen to and nothing to compare it to and now I feel much better. :)

 

I’m hoping that this cold weather goes away soon. It is really messing with all of our voices and our health. We open a week from Friday and I really want the warmth back. Everyone stills sounds amazing, but if it keeps going on like this, it is going to have a bigger effect on our voices. *sigh* Sometimes it sucks being a singer...

 

Rehearsal was good tonight, though all of us are really low on energy. I think everyone really needs some time off. We have Saturday off, which is excellent. My friends from the VT faire are having a b-day party on saturday and I’m starting to feel a little stir-crazy here. So I’m gonna make the drive down to them (I think its like an hour and 1/2) and visit with them on Saturday. I think I’ve been staying in too much...you all know me, I have to do like 10 million things at once, and all I’ve been doing is staying in and reading. So I need to go out and explore around town a little more and get out. The problem with this is of course that the weather just sucks, so being outside is not the best idea for la voce. Here’s hoping that things change weather-wise.

Good news first:

I was just cast as The Witch in the opera Hansel & Gretel in Boston with Opera del West! YAY!! So you'll all be able to come and see me - no excuses. lol! The show goes into rehearsal the weekend after I get back, so I REALLY have my work cut out for me. EEK! But yay! It is an awesome role and tons of fun. I'm shocked and totally psyched!

Now for more news on the VT front:

 Monday

 

Monday was busy busy busy!! We had rehearsal with the chorus all day. It was crazy. The act II finale is the big sextet and the chorus is involved (it is all guys) and there is so much going on on stage... I think everyone is going to enjoy this. It is funny and nuts and has everything you could imagine, and probably things you wouldn’t imagine. ;) Meredith and I think it is fun being the only girls in a cast full of guys. :) 

 

We had a sitzprobe at night with the orchestra. If I didn’t explain before, a “sitz” as we call it is when we rehearse with the orchestra to figure out tempos and such. The singers sit on the stage and we stand when we have to sing. It’s a loooooooooooooonnnggg and arduous process, but we managed to make it fun. It was also decided that we would be hosting a bbq night @ our house the next day. YAY! This house is definitely meant for partying.

 

Not much else to report for Monday...they gave us Tuesday off because everyone is getting allergies and we are all looking and sounding a little tired. This stuff is hard to sing and some people sing constantly...so we could all use the break. I don’t sing as much as everyone else and I’m exhausted. I can’t imagine how everyone else feels.

 

 

Tuesday

 

Day off! YAY! The conductor and I came into town for a bit we are all working off of 2 different scores (including the orchestra) and he was doing comparisons of the 2. They are incredibly different, so he wanted to order one of the other scores which is much better for the orchestra. I got to catch up on some e-mail and do a little business in town. :) Then we headed to the store to pick up essentials for the bbq. 

 

I had part of the day to sit outside and just read and breathe for a while. It has been quite cold, but when the sun shines, it is warm and lovely by the lake. I can’t tell you how much I needed this time. I feel to invigorated. The mountains do that to me. :) The nights have been in the 30s eek. Thank god we have heat. The weekend was hot though. Don’t you just love New England and it’s crazy weather patterns??

 

The BBQ was a blast. We all laughed and made fun of each other. We got the cast (which are about 7-8 total), the conductor, the stage manager and our artistic director to come. The evening was cool, but still nice, so we got to hang outside for a bit. :) Some of the boys are on the other side of the lake from us, so they are going to host a bbq night for us as well...

 

Tomorrow I don’t have rehearsal until about 2:00, so I plan to sleep in a little and clean up around the house. We have a cleaning lady coming in, thank god. But I want to get my room a little more organized. I plan on going into town a little early to post this. We have rehearsal ending @ 4:00 so we can have time to eat dinner and then go watch the Met’s broadcast of “THE AUDITION” which is a documentary they did on their annual competition that they have all over the country. I’ve already seen it, but I’d love to see it again. I think it is very beneficial to all singers to see the whole process. 

 

Hope all is well at home! I’ll see some of you in a few weeks!

Since I don't really have tons of internet access, these posts will be kinda sporadic. :)

Thursday

I sit here out on the lake at 9:30 pm, the sky is mostly dark and the stars are starting to show. The lake is quiet except for the frogs happily singing. Yes, that’s right, frogs do sing. :) Day two in Vermont brought pretty scenes, lots of heat, tons of laughs and a little bit o stress. :)

 

I started the day by waking up @ 7:30. If you know me, that’s late. My rehearsal didn’t start until 11:30. Which is amazing. My rehearsals @ BASOTI and in Italy always started at 9. It was more a company meeting. We met all the other cast members. Meredith and I are the only girls. Which is all sorts of crazy and fun. After the meeting, I wasn’t called for about 45 minutes, so I walked around the town a bit with one of the cast members who actually recognized me from Hartt. It was good catching up and he’s been in a show here before, so he showed me to all of the fun spots. There is a beautiful waterfall around the corner from the theater. There is also a little coffee shop that has given all of us singers 9 free coffees. They are very sweet and were kind of a hang out spot for the cast last year. 

 

Rehearsals were great and passed in a whirlwind... the way the director works is fun. He kind flies through things and is more of a theater person, which I think is so good for opera. It gives us all a fresh perspective. He is very much someone who is willing to work with you and take your ideas into account. I love people like that.

 

So, not much else to report. I’m pretty exhausted. I shouldn’t be, but I am. I blame the heat...mostly. Tomorrow we have a meet the singers event where we will meet people who “adopted” us. There were several donors who basically adopted us and helped pay our contracts here with the company. It’s a good idea and so far everyone has been so great to us. They told us that tomorrow’s event is always a lot of fun. We’re singing things that are not from the show, which is a nice change. I’m singing my russian aria which is the polar opposite from what I sing in the opera. lol. But it is gorgeous and they requested that I sing it. :) 

 

Ok, I’m rambling and I’m tired. So tomorrow, I’m sleeping in cuz I’m not called until later and I plan on doing a little canoeing on the lake! I love this lake! *sigh*


Friday

 

Yay for kind of sleeping in. The Conductor and Meredith had an earlier call today, so, I couldn’t sleep too late. And for some reason my cell phone shuts off at 4 am here because of low battery, even though I charged it to full capacity...weird. So that wakes me up. But NO MOCKINGBIRD! lol. 

 

So we had breakfast and went through our music. I must say how wonderful it is to be in a professional production where you go over your tempi with the conductor. Especially a cool one like ours who is really flexible. We had a great deal to talk about this morning. it was sunny and beautiful for the morning, and around noon when they left, it got cloudy. I decided against the canoe today since we had to sing at the Meet the Singers event later on. Lord knows with my luck, I’d end up hurting myself somehow. tee hee.

 

I went grocery shopping instead. On the way, I passed a A&W diner where the waitresses are on roller skates. LUV IT! It is mostly countryside with fields and mountains not too far off. So gorgeous. I spent the rest of the afternoon getting ready for the concert and going over my music.

 

The meet the singers event was fun. Lots of schmoozing. Everyone here is so ridiculously nice and so accomodating. We’re getting spoiled. I wish every company would treat their singers like this. Its awesome. Everyone sang well. My piece went ok. I kinda lost it at the very very end of my aria, but if you don’t know the piece, it wasn’t noticeable. Meredith and I stuck together during the cocktail hour and had to dodge all the guys trying to make us laugh while we were speaking to the donors. I know I’ve already said this, but the guys are all hilarious. We actually met a composer who lives here in Middlebury and composed a new work for Fort Worth opera. Jonathan Blalock, who is playing our Count Almaviva here is actually going to be in it as well. Coolness. The opera world is SUCH a small world!

 

We had a rehearsal with the orchestra directly after. It is called a sitzprobe where we all sit and sing along with them. The orchestra is quite good, they are smaller, but still very talented and very nice. Unfortunately, about 1/4 of the way through rehearsal I started getting a horrible tension headache. IT was awful. I had to sing the insane 140+ page sextet with a headache. I didn’t let it bother me, but part of singing is letting the sound go through the top of your head, and if you have a headache, you can’t really feel the sound. It is kind of a block and it feels like you cant get anything through. So that was a challenge. Luckily, we stopped right before my aria. Phew! We had fun though, of course we laughed a lot. 

 

We were all soooo exhausted and starving afterwards. Our eating patterns here are not normal. We can go without having time for food for about 8 hours. Its kinda nuts. But that’s ok. We’re rushing through everything and don’t even realize that we are hungry until we are done. :)

Here I am in Salisbury, VT which is right outside of Middlebury, where my opera will be held in a few weeks. The trip was a good 4 hours with one stop for gas. It was a little slow in 2 places, but that’s ok. The trip was truly lovely with winding roads and towering mountains. *sigh* I love Vermont. It always feels like home here. Some people like the beach, I prefer the forest and the mountains. They make me so calm. Its hard to explain. Anyway, I drove past Killington ski area, which is so weird to see without snow! 

 

The ride was not as bad as I thought it would be. I expected to be aggitated and bored with the slow pace for a while, but that didn’t happen at all. It must be part of the affect this place has on me...

 

I got here at about 4:00. I met the Stage Manager at the theater and she took me to the place where I am staying with the other female in the cast (the lead role of Rosina) and our conductor. It is about 15 minutes outside of town and HOLY CRAP! It is on a lake. LITERALLY on a lake. I walk out my door and 30 feet later - lake and mountain. *sigh* I love it and I already don’t want to leave. We were told that we get the better of the accomodations...um YAH! We are in a “summer home” which basically looks like a large cabin, but the inside is all leather couches and looks like a ski lodge. We have a cleaning lady who is coming in once a week and all have our own rather large bedrooms. I get the smallest, cuz I am the last one here, but who cares! It is still bigger than my room at home! There is a covered porch and then a deck. There are canoes!! I looooooove canoeing. Srsly. Haven’t done it in years but die a little inside every time I see one and can’t go out on it. So you better believe I am taking advantage of that!

 

I met some of the cast tonight. They had a little rehearsal of a few scenes since not everyone is here yet. I got to rehearse my aria for the meet the singers event on Friday which is when we all sing a little something not from the opera for the locals to enjoy and to encourage them to come see the opera. (Which, BTW Sunday is almost sold out!!) It went well. I got to watch the blocking a little. This cast is GOOD. I mean really really good. And they are all very nice so far and hilarious. They make it a point up here not to hire anyone stuffy and not willing to take some chances. Which makes me happy. I actually have a lot in common with the other girl - Meredith. She is a friend of a few of the people I went to Hartt in CT with. They weren’t my best friends when I was there, but she is cool and they are ok. So we were exchanging stories. I also discovered that I went to Hartt with one of the guys in the cast. I didn’t know him well back then, but he was the one who realized it. We both looked at each other and were like, I know you. He firgured it out. :) You know me, I can’t remember what happened yesterday anymore! 

 

Anyway, after a little bit of rehearsal, I went to the grocery store. Did I mention we have a MASSIVE KITCHEN??? Yah, we do. So, I went home and was on my own for a bit - yay! I went outside by the lake with my dinner and just sat and relaxed. *sigh* It is so gorgeous here. I promise to post some pics soon. The funny thing is I was just saying how much I need a vacation. And no matter how stressful this all turns out to be...I will enjoy that lake. Just being here makes it all better.

 

Ok, I am tired. I don’t have wireless access here, so that is the downside. I have to steal it when I can, so chances are you will be getting this the day after I write as I tend to write at night when all is said and done. :) And my phone doesn’t work in the house, only outside...I know, weir. But it DOES tell me when I have voicemail, so if you want to call me and I don’t answer, leave a message and I will get back to you. If I’m not at the house, I pretty much have reception everywhere. So, that’s good. :) I’ll post whenever I can. Catch you all later!

For those of you who have been wondering what the heck I have been doing for the past couple of months, here's a little update!

After spending endless weekends dragging myself from Boston to NYC for auditions most of the winter, I am soooooooo excited to announce that I have just been hired to sing with Opera Company of Middlebury this summer in their production of Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" aka "The Barber of Seville". I will be playing the role of Berta who is the maid in a crazy household. She is the comic relief - which is not a stretch for me - ha ha!
 
This opera is TONS of fun and hilariously funny. If some of you have never seen or heard an opera before, this is an excellent production to ease into it!
 
The show will be on June 5,7,9 & 11. The performances will take place at the Town Hall Theater in Middlebury, Vermontwhich is about an hour south of Burlington. Yes, it is a ways away from Boston. But hey - road trip! And Vermont is GORGEOUS in June!
 
You can check out http://www.ocmvermont.org/ for more details. (Yes, that is me in the bottom right hand corner!)
 
I hope some of you can make it! I'll be sending more info as the date gets closer!

Wow. It has been waaaaay to long! Now that things seem to be moving right along, I think I will be posting here more often about my musical adventures. 

Let's see... where did we leave off? Ah yes, the Opera Idol competition. How fun that was!!

After that, in December, I was back and forth from Boston to New York for many auditions for various companies/programs all over the world. The most exciting news and more relevant to my sigining endeavors is the story about how I will be doing a program with ILAR this summer in Rome! YAY!

In December, I met up with my dear friend and fellow mezzo-soprano, Brianne who I was fortunate enough to meet @ BASOTI this summer. She flew in from Wisconsin and we spent two fun-filled days in New York for our various auditions. Our travel plans were insane, so it was a whirlwind of a few days!

My audition was the day after we arrived in the Big Apple and it was weird. To convey the craziness and excitement to you all, I will take an entry from my personal journal - 

"My voice teacher was one of the people listening to the auditions as she is teaching there this summer. Oh, I should probably tell you that this is for a summer program in Rome for all of July. 

So after their break, I went in. They all looked very very serious, except for my teacher. She was smily but stern. ha ha. I gave them my resume, repetoire list and introduced myself and my first piece. I sang my best aria from Barber of Seville. The one where everyone tells me that I will be doing that role for the rest of my life. It went very well. Not perfect, but under the conditions that I had to sing under, pretty damn well. I was ok with it. :) I didn't get much of a reaction, but there were a few smiles. It is a funny aria after all. After I finished they all began speaking in Italian right in front of me. It is weird to have people talk about you in another language right in front of you. LOL. That was quite an experience. So then they asked me to give them a minute and to step outside. When they asked me back in, my teacher (who was translating) told me that they would like me to do the role of 2nd lady in The magic Flute as well. YAY! I was kind of indifferent, but very gracious and thanked them all in Italian. They were so nice. And then the Maestro who was the most serious-looking out of all of them told Andrea (my teacher) to tell me that if he was doing the Barber of Seville right now He would give me the role tomorrow and I would be on a plane to Italy that same night. Wow. Biggest compliment ever! Of course, I was so tired and overwhelmed that none of this hit me until this weekend! It took several days for it all to settle in. :) Then I realized that the Maestro is the head of the largest Rossini festival in the world and is considered to be an expert in Rossini (who is the composer who wrote Barber of Seville). So, basically the world's biggest expert in Rossini gave me the ultimate compliment. HOLY CRAP!"

I would be doing the role and recitals. In addition to that there would be exclusive opportunities to sing for agents in Rome (including La Scala) and composers as well. And it is nationally televised. Then after the performances in Rome we would be going on tour with the opera for 2 weeks all over Italy. It would be reviewed by local media as well. So how can one pass up that opportunity??

When I came home, I discovered that my performance of Bertha's aria and the lack of people that they had audition for Rigoletto, has made them decided to do Barber of Seville. Nothing is for certain yet, but I may be doing the role of Bertha as well as the role in the Magic Flute! WHEE!!! 

This is all very exciting! And I have sent in my contract to be part of the program. It is an experience that I cannot pass up!

My voice has also grown a great deal in the past month or so. I've been working very dilligently toward trying to get to where I need to be in the voice. And I am soooo excited for all of the possibilities that the new sound has opened up. My voice has become huge and it is so much fun to work with!! 

Other than that I am playing the role of "Leila" in Iolanthe. Which is a Gilbert & Sullivan Operetta that is being put on by Mass Theatrica and NEGASS in Sudbury, MA on March 9th. It is a sing through/sing along which means that the people in the audience get to sing the choral parts! WHEE!! I hope some of you can make it! 

After that I may audition for Godspell, but that depends purely on how much memorization I can get through for the Magic Flute and Suor Angelica. Oh, which btw I am doing in September now instead of June. The opera company wanted to market the opera a little more, so they felt it best to change the dates to the end of September. Which is actually kind of a relief. I will have a little less stress this way. :)

I am so excited for all of my upcoming opportunities and I promise that I will update more as information becomes available! Hugs n kisses!!

This is my last post from San Francisco. WAH! Actually, by the time most of you read this, I will probably already be home. My flight leaves @ 2:10 tomorow and gets in late at night. Weather is not supposed to be happy all across the country, so here's hoping that the turbulence stays at a minimum! I don't do well with turbulence.

My last few days here have been great. Thursday night I went to a goodbye party. I stayed out waaay too late. But it was so worth it. Everyone just had a blast and we took over the Bitter End, which is a bar that everyone from BASOTI frequents. I had to wake up early the next day to sing in acting though. So staying out late was not a very good idea. But that is ok! :) Friday morning I woke up and went to acting. When I was warming up, I didn't sound too good. But acting is not so much about the sound as it is about other things. We started with a scene between two sisters, one of which had gotten her "dream job" but since their mother was sick, the sister answered a letter for her and she lost the job. Lots of break throughs happened and some walls that had been blocked started to crumble. It was interesting to watch. 

When it came time for me to go up and do a scene, I was psyched. I love the way this guy works. He gets such amazing results out of people and helps them get to untouched places to portray a role. I sang "Must the winter come so soon" which is a melancholy piece that is really beautiful. Katy was in the scene with me and she sang a gorgeous aria from "Susanna" about a young girl describing her home and how she wants to get away one day. So the scene that Katy was a young prodigy who was unbelievable at the piano and could also sing. I was her mother, and ever since she was little, I knew that she had a natural talent and tried to get her in with the right people. I was also blind. Oh yay! So my daughter, now 17, came to me and told me that she got into her favorite school. My reaction was to be happy for her, but quietly happy and not really sad, but still melancholy. Holy crap that was hard. So he kept telling me to be still and almost whisper. Then I had to sing my song. It had to be super quiet, which was also difficult. But it felt great. So I told her that I was happy for her after it ended and to tell me what Julliard is like. She then began to sing her aria. She had to act like she was telling me what new york was like she was singing, the song talked about going to the city. So it worked really well. :) But as she was singing, she really blossomed. It was so moving. There was a moment in the aria when it was instrumental and I said "It sounds beautiful". Then I began to cry. Not from sadness, but because I had a blindfold on and I could still see what she was talking about in my head. I was crying more from happiness for her than for sadness that I was losing her. It was so intense. What an incredible feeling! 

Our comments from the teacher and from the audience was that they were so engrossed that they could have let us go on for hours. Wow. He said that I am so charismatic and that this side of me is so enrapturing that I need to try and let things happen than forcing them to. Not that I force things, but this vulnerability and sense of stillness was so moving. So he gave me a new motto and wants me to put it on my desk and all of my mirrors at home - Reveal not Project. He said that my charisma alone is enough to keep people's attention and to just let things happen will be my strongest ability. I wish I could tell you how amazing that all felt. I feel transformed somehow. It is so cool. A couple of us asked him for reccomendations for teachers in New York. He gave us a few names and those of us in the area are going to get together like once a month to go to class. Sounds fun, no?

Friday after acting a few of us went to lunch and then I went to Union Square to pick up a few things before packing. I thought I was going to have to buy another suitcase becuase I have sooooo much stuff. But luckily, I have managed to pack all of it up. I'm sure that I'll have to pay overweightcharges,but whatever! That is ok by me. Tartuffe is a weeeeeiiiirrrrdd opera! Funny at times, but pretty weird. The conductor was there for the first evening last night. He wrote it many many many years ago and is a big supporter of BASOTI, so the organization gave him a plaque commemorating the occassion. I think it was like the 25th anniversary of the opera? Not too sure. 

I went home to pack after the performance, people had a gala to sing in today and I had major packing to do, so we allwent home. This morning, I was able to pack some more up and was able to go to brunch with about 8 others from the program. Afterwards, we all went to the gala for the final scenes program. Then we all went to PIZZA ORGASMICA for one final pizza. We sat in the orgasmica room which has low tables and cushions ot sit on. There were about 25 of us, and sillyness abounded. So, now I am home and finishing up the rest of my packing and trying not to be too upset. ha ha. I had to say goodbye to many today. Many are trying to meet later on tonight, but many are not able to make it. *sigh* So it has been a rough day, but still good! And the sun finally came out today. It has been so cold an dreary this week. Almost like San Francisco is saying - don't go! Which is what everyone was saying on Thursday night - don't go, stay here! I wish I could. this place has grown on my sooo much. 

But alas, I have to go home. I have obligations to fulfill, but maybe one day I will end up here. :)

Ok folks, this is Gils in San Francisco for her final night, signing off and saying GOOD BYE SAN FRANCISCO! I WILL MISS YOU!

It is Thursday afternoon here on the West Coast and for the past 3 days it has been FREEZING. Colder than it has been so far. Bleh. I was hoping it would be sunny my last week here so I could take pretty pictures. Nope. Doesn't work that way.

Tuesday morning I was supposed to go to Acting Class, but my back REALLY hurt and I was up late the night before reading the rest of the new Harry Potter (EEK!). I couldn't get my act together to go to class. So I slept in. That was my last day for it. *sigh* Back to early mornings until my next day off from work. blah! I got up and had lunch and decided to go to Chinatown - loved it! I had tea at a tea tasting bar, got myself a silk kimono and bought a new huge tiara for the PRINCIPESSA! WHEEE!! I love the tiara, and it was not expensive. To get to chinatown, I took a cable car. It was windy and cold, but well worth it. Cable cars are awesome. Cuz let me tell you, climbing these hills SUUUUCKS! And it doesn't matter what kind of shape you are in, it NEVER gets easier. Anyway, chinatown = fun. I took a bunch of pictures which I will post later. I also went to Clarion Music Center which has really funky instruments. Got some ankle bells for the act.

Because I was so close to Union Square, I decided to go there and check out Loehmann's which has great designer things for a fraction of the price. I found a few things that I like, but didn't get anything. I was a good girl. :) So, once again I went on a quest for Versace, this time with a map in hand. It wasn't there. They must have gone out of business here in the Bay Area. *sniff sniff* But I went to Juicy and a few other places to make myself feel better - tee hee! Then I went home. I was exhausted, so I just stayed in. 

Wednesday, I got up for acting. The class was AMAZING. It was conducted by Bobby Wineapple who is just INCREDIBLE. He gets people to do things that you would never think they are capable of doing. He asked me to sing first since he hadn't seen/heard me yet and had already worked with everyone in the class (not many people had shown up). So I did Berta's aria and he chuckled and then said to me. Giliana, what do you want to be when you grow up? Everyone giggled. So I said, in my cutest voice - I wanna be an opera singer! So he said, right, and how big are opera houses? I said, anywhere from 200-3,000 people! He said - exactly! So, I want you to make this bigger. I want you to go crazy and just make it ridiculous and over the top. So I said ok. He told me to keep that in mind and sit down. Then he asked the guys in the class what they brought to sing. One (who is a bit of a drama queen and a baby) said that he just wanted to watch and didn't really want to sing. The second, Ian, brought a comic aria as well. So Bobby had him sing through it and then he had us set up an improv scene. Ian is a Jack from Will & Grace-like character who is famous and lives in Hollywood. The other guy, Joe, was playing a Sylvester Stallone-like action hero who is also famous, but is gay. And if anyone finds out, it would ruin his career. He & Ian are in love. And me? I'm a fag-hag who is hired to be on Joe's arm. I fall in love with Ian and we have one night together, but he is now denying it. So, I become crazed and threaten to go to the press. 

The scene starts and Joe is not into it. Ian come running in and starts to try to explain what is happening to Joe. I come running in about a minute later and start flipping out. So, the scene excalates and I have to go crazy to try and make IAN love me. The director is shouting directions to us as the scenes go on. So he says, preted that you are going to kill yourself. I grab a pillow and pretend to smother myself, when they both don't notice (after being very dramatic and almost dying), I run @ Ian, throw myself on the floor and grab his leg. I don't let go and he drags me all over the floor - and then his aria starts. I'm still holding onto him and screaming. lol!! The people who are watching are DYING at this point. Everyone is laughing so hard that they are literally falling off their chairs and can't breathe. It was sooo funny. Then Ian finishes his aria and I have to grab onto him and try to threaten Joe. Then I hear my music. So, at this point, I have to be like homicidal. So I take the pillow and hit it threateningly towards the two of them. And then I do my aria while threatening them. The director keeps telling me that I have to go bigger and do more. So by then end, I'm in the middle of the stage, singing my high notes and then I fall into a heap on the floor with my hair wild and all over the place. It was amazing and fun and crazy and it felt great! I loved it!! There was another scene with a couple of people after us that made us all cry. But I won't tell you about that one. It is really depressing.

After class a whole bunch of us went for lunch. It was great to spend time with some of these people. I haven't seen most of them as they were all in other scenes and operas and we haven't had times that overlap. After lunch, I went to see the famous "painted ladies" - the row of victorian houses up on Alamo Square. It was so foggy and so cold that the view of the city wasn't great, but I did some good shots of the houses. :) After walking the hill, I went to say goodbye to Fisherman's wharf. I went to Ghiradelli Square for some souvenirs and then I went to Lori's Diner for dinner. It is a cool 50s themed diner that is all over the city. Very fun place and good food! So, I walked around the wharf for a bit and pier 39 and tried to find the "crookedest street" which I did see, but it was late so I couldn't get a good picture. The street is crooked because it was so steep that you have to drive on it from side to side in order to go down. Scary! Since it was getting darker and colder, I went home.

Today I went to acting class again. It was fantastic! Didn't get to do much today, I mostly watched, but he is writing a scene for me for tomorrow. YAY! After class a few of us went to help one of the girls find a gown for the final gala this weekend. They have a formal event at the Legion of Honor every year here and it is pretty much black tie. This girl didn't have a dress and was pretty clueless, so we went to the Jessica McClintock Outlet. DRESSES GALORE and for less than $30!! It was insane! But so fun. So now I am resting a bit and trying to start packing. Tonight I have to introduce some of the girls to the wonder that is MAC makeup and then we are all going to a local bar because one of the guys is leaving tomorrow to go home. So the first of the final parties has begun. :) Tomorrow I have class and then I have to go to Union Square to pick some things up and also to Haight Ashbury to visit the hippies. lol. Tartuffe is the final opera here and it starts tomorrow night. So I am heading to that. Saturday early afternoon is the Gala which we are all required to go to and then Saturday night is another of the final goodbye parties. lol. The final final goodbye is on Sunday when I am not here. So Sunday late morning I head to the airport and fly home. *sigh*

It feels weird that I have to pack everything already. *sigh* But that is ok. My memories will keep me going for a looong time and there is so much waiting for me @ home! :)

Tonight I went to a masterclass that was a big waste of time. The master who was giving the class didn't say much that I agree with. But that is ok, it happens. I didn't sing - thank god! But those that did were not very happy. Afterwards, a bunch of us went to Pizza Orgasmica. Yes, the pizza is that good. lol. And we were all sharing stories of how we enjoyed the program and what we've gotten out of it. Then we all started going into our histories and how we ended up there.

There was this one girl who is a little awkward there. She is sooo sweet, and I really really like her. She is a composer and has only recently discovered the world of opera. Mostly self-trained as a mezzo-soprano, she is very cool and doesn't have any music background except for being part of a chorus or two. We were all talking about how we see ourselves and if we actually think if we have what it takes to make it. She had seen me this weekend in Silla and told me that she loved my performance as God and she also saw me in some scenes as her scenes were the same night. She was like, how could you think that you aren't meant for this? I said how we are all our own worst ciritcs and explained my history. She told me that she thinks that I am amazing and how she loves my voice. I said thank you. And she looked at me and said - can I give you a weird compliment? I said - sure! 

She asked me if I knew who Linda Rondstat was. I was like - of course! Everyone else at the table also replied the same thing. She is great - of course we know who she is!! :) So she went on about how she and her mom were really close friends and have been since they were young. She told us stories about how she would come to the house. Someone didn't believe her, so she was like, WAIT! I think I have a picture. So, she pulled out a picture, sure enough, there she was with her sister, her mom and Linda Rondstat.COOLNESS! So, then we all got the shock of our lives when she said that Linda came to the scenes programs that she was in with her mom. WHAT??? Linda Rondstat was within 15 feet of us and we didn't know?!?!?! AHHH! So she said, yah, she was. And let me tell you that she had a lot to say about you Giliana. I was drinking at the time and had to spit out my drink to not choke on it? I almost dropped my glass of water and said "Excuse me?" She said - yah, she said that you seemed very sweet and that you had a beautiful voice. She also said that you were charismatic and that she thought that you have a very bright future. "Are you serious?" I said. Yes, I am,she said. Totally nonchalantly! She said, so don't you dare say that you aren't meant for this.

OH. MY. GOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Friggin Linda Rondstat thinks that I am good??? This cannot be real! This has to be a lie or something. HOLY CRAP! I've never felt more honored in my life. I was in complete SHOCK. Words... there were no words!

So, now that the initial shock of it has worn off. Let me tell you about how the weekend went. Friday we had one last dress rehearsal in the afternoon. Whoever had that idea is not cool in my book. It was very difficult. When we all should have been resting, we were having dress rehearsal and working our asses off. Ah, the theater. Gotta love it. 

The performance went REALLY well. It was my silent role night. We opened to a packed house with standing room only. The audience LOVED the opera. It turned out to be very funny actually. When I came on stage with my dorky glasses and waiter-like outfit, people laughed their asses off. Especially the ones that knew me. Everyone afterward said that I stole the show. And it wasn't intentional. It wasn't meant to be funny. Well, not really. But it was - lol. There was only one little hitch in the whole night, which was not noticeable to the audience, so that is fine. :) After the opera, we hada champagne reception in the hall to celebrate the US premiere of the opera. Everyone was decked out in gowns and jewels and it was quite the shindig. I was approached by the artisitc director and her husband who said - wow Gliana. That was perfect, it wasn't overwhelming, it was just the right amount. You didn't take away from the scene but you made your presence known. This really showed off your acting ability. To which I replied - Thanks! I guess I should not sing more often! They all laughed heartily at that. 

The next day was my day to be GOD! YAY! I slept a litle late and went to be supportive to some of my colleagues, they had a scenes program that day. It was really good. Some I was entirely unimpressed with, but there were a few people that were fabulous. They also did a one act opera that was originally composed by mozart about the craziness of the opera business. Basically about 2 feuding sopranos. It has since been translated to english many many times and is just hilarious. We all laughed our asses off. I was glad that I got to see it. 

Just a few short hours later, I was in makeup and ready to be GOD. lol. I didn't get as many laughs as Nick did. He has this natural ability to be silly. And he really hammed the GOD thing up. It is hard to describe. But it was a riot. I was more look at me, I am god - love me worship me and I am pretty and regal. Naturally. ;) The aria didn't go as well as I'd hoped. Well, in my opinion anyway. Everyone else did a great job. There was one little mishap with one of the sopranos, she came in a little early and off key, but hey, it happens! 

Afterwards, we again had champagne and again the opera was REALLY well received. Compliments abounded for everyone involved. Me? I gots tons, which I really didn't expect. I wish I could explain to you how challenging this aria was for me. I was a little nervous about what people would say. I got nothing but THat was fantatics! OR Wow, Giliana! Some of my colleagues came to all three performances and approachd me and said - ya know, I thought you did a much better job than Nick. They said that they loved him, but he almost took away from the opera. He didn't play it regally, he played it like a ham. And they all liked my aproach more. I got a big hug and a kiss from the aritistic director and her husband. They were thrilled with my performance. It was really shocking. 

I've just had shocks left and right! It has been quite a few days! Sunday also went really well. I was so done with everything already though. lol. After we struck the set, we were supposed to have a cast party. We did, but not many people showed up. It was fun, but short lived. Eh, my parties are always better anyway. lol. We go ALL out when we throw parties, these people have NO Idea how to throw a party like me! ha ha!

Anywho, less than a week to go and I will be home. WEIRDNESS! I am looking forward to hearing about everyone's adventures over the summer and have lots more of my own to tell!

I was suddenly woken by a very large boom and felt the house shake for 1/2 a second. Thinking oh, it was that stupid motorcycle that always wakes me up at night, I went to sleep. My street sometimes has loud noises. I've gotten pretty used to them.

Literally! My costume is partly gold lame! LMAO! I am playing god and i have a cape - and it is fantastic! LOL! We open tomorrow night (Friday, July 20). Yay! I play a silent role tomorrow and Sunday and then I play God on Saturday. Tuesday's rehearsal was fairly simple. I didn't have to sing. Yay. It was our first night with the orchestra, so it was a ROUGH night. Monday was also a little rough. It was my second time doing the aria with staging and the first on stage. The Artistic Director and her husband (one of the conductors) were there to see us. They left almost right after my aria, but before they went, they gave me a few insights. Mathias (the conductor of Cosi) was very very concerned that the aria was being taken way to fast and insisted on telling Jennifer, our conductor for Silla. He is a great guy and really wants to see us all succeed. So, it was good to hear from him. Syvia was telling me to sing through things, which I totally agree with. But the day she heard me was not a good one. I had so much crap in my throat from getting over the damn cold I had, that is was sort of preventing me from getting the sount out. Plus, the aria is kind of hard and I was stil sooo tentative on it. Which is what my director told me that same evening. Yes, I said, I know and I promised it would be fine by today. Wednesday was a fun day for me. I went to do some shopping on Fillmore St. the day before because I had saved some extra cash and nothing makes me feel better than shoppin! LOL! So, I went to MAC for some makeup because I was almost out of some things. Had a BLAST there and got my new PRO ID card which gives me 30% off - can you say it with me? EEEEEE! lol. And teh funny thing was that it was in this random place that was really really nice and schmancy! Weirdness! On the way back to the bus, I heard my phone beep. Thinking it was my mom, I caled my voicemail. I had spoken to her earlier as it was the anniversary of a very very good friend's death and we were remembering her fondly. So, I thought maybe she wanted to say something else. I press 1 to hear my messages... and hear the dulcet tones of a tenor voice. :) It was Eli singing "Un aura amarosa" from Cosi! EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!!!! I was grinning like a GEEK! It was fantastic! I was so excited that I almost knocked someone over on the side walk. lol!!! BTW - if you want to hear him/see him sing it you can go to - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=39zcFvJe41I it doesn't really do him justice. The live version is waaaaay better - but you can get the idea. I just adore him for doing that. He is the bestest! This kid is so unbelievably talented and still so young. I can't praise him enough. :) I'm not easily impressed, which is why I can't stop raving. Tee hee. So anyway, that night I had a dress rehearsal before my final dress on thursday. It went well. Not too bad. I was much less tentative. But unfortunately, I had a bit of a breakdown. One of the other sopranos came up to me and said What is that high note that you sing in the aria? For some reason my computer has decided to say that today is Wednesday the 18th. I actually believed it for a while. I am so confused. 

Let me tell you that having a major role in an opera takes every single ounce of energy that one could possibly possess!! I didn't think that I could be as tired as I was yesterday. i am serious! We ran through the opera once with one cast, and then ran through the opera a second time with another. There are 3 different casts. But to run through it 2 times in a 5 hour period is just deadly. I could barely keep my eyes open at the end of the night. And then we had to sit around and wait for notes, which took forever. 

At home I averaged about 4-5 hours a night of sleep. Here, I need to get at least 8-9 or I am pooped! My teacher used to tell me that you have to rest a great deal before a performance. I never really thought about it, but it is really true. No wonder people put themselves on vocal rest and take a few days off before performing. Sheesh!!

Sunday was a busy day. I had a loooooong day with rehearsal @ 12:00-5:00 and then the last show for Cosi @ 8:00. The show went well. But I somehow ended up with only 1 character shoe. lol! Don't know how that happened. So I had to do the show barefoot. ha ha! This stuff only happens to me. It is quite amusing. That night was an interesting one to say the least. After the show, we all went to Mel's diner to grab some dinner and to decompress. If you know anything about theater, decompression is absolutely necessary! That is why we party afterwards. ;) It was fun. I got to spend some time outside of rehearsals with my fellow cast -mates which was great! They are a hilarious group of people! I was out a little too late though. I had to sing the next day, so I left at about 1:00am. Luckily, there was a bus right next to the diner and the driver was grabbing coffee, so I ran to the bus and hopped on. It was only a few stops to my street - yay!

Staying out that late was probably not a very good idea though. It is probably why I was 1/2 dead yesterday. I did get to sleep late, but I stil didn't feel rested. Note to self: Don't do that when you have to sing the next day! It was worth it though. All kinds of memories were made that night! 

So Monday I had rehearsal @ 3:30pm. I ran some errands and went to Silla at the Conservatory. I love that the conservatory is only about 6-7 stops by bus. So much easier than going to the school on the other side of town. It was tough day for everyone. There were a lot of de-railments and a lot of breakdowns. They are all so stressed. I had a really fascinating conversation with some of the other members of the cast. They all hate BASOTI with a passion. Most of them have only been doing Silla and nothing else. While I have loved every moment of the program. I mean, I see why they hate it. They have a difficult director and a difficult conductor. They are all so stressed that you can see it in every move they make. None of them are having any fun. And ya know, if you don't enjoy it, the audience won't either. And that is the worst thing that can happen. It is awful and just a shame. I know that the reason I am having fun is becuase the people in my scenes and in Cosi are amazing and they are all so supportive, while in Silla they are kind of cut-throat and not very supportive. It is like night and day. I feel bad for them, but at the same time, I don't. You have to take what you can and learn what you can from these things. If people tried to see it in a different light, they might enjoy it more. But then again, my background is so different. I have been through hell. These people really haven't. So, I came with a different attitude. I mean, I also came into this about 1/2 way through, so I haven't seen as much as they have, but I think I am fairly perceptive. Ya know?

Anyway, rehearsal tonight from 5-10. Then tomorrow and the next day and then I have rehearsal all day on friday and a show friday, saturday and sunday - then I am done. And one week after that - I come home. EEK! Kinda scary. Don't know what it is going to be like to be thrown back into life. But I'm sure I will be fine. ;) I always am.

Woke up today to my phone ringing @ about 5:00am! WHAT? It was a number from home. Probably a wrong number, even if it wasn't - it is a 3 hour time difference! ARGH!

I got to rehearsal at 11:00 only to find out that am rehearsal was cancelled and no one thought to call me- thanks people! Didn't have enough time to go back to my place before the scenes programs started, and I wanted to be supportive and watch the scenes, so I stuck around BASOTI all morning. I helped in the office and went out for Dim Sum. Ah dim sum - how I shall miss you when I go home!

The program was good, but I had to go to Silla rehearsal from 4-7 which was before the program ended. Darnit. My call for Cosi was at 7:00 as well, now how I am supposed to be there in a flash when it take at least a 1/2 an hour from BASOTI to the Conservatory where we are performing is beyond me. Not to mention,my stuff was all at my apartment because I hadn't anticipated this change of scheduling. So, yah, little stressful. We had a full runthrough of Silla for the first time. Didn't go too badly. I still don't have this stuff under my belt completely, but I will by the time we have to perform it on Friday. :)

Cosi went very well. Our first performance, and it went off without a hitch. It was bittersweet as there are 2 casts and 2 nights. The tenor who I adore - Eli, only sang tonight, so I only got to hear him sing one last time tonight. *sigh* He is fantastic. :) Fame written all over him. And yes, I know that I said that before, but it is true! And the aria I am talking about is very famous and one of the most beautiful tenor arias ever written. It is called "Un aura amarosa" from Cosi fan Tutte. Listen to it - it is gorgeous!
