Look at him! I swear he was saying - "Look at me! I'm so cute! You got my picture?" He kept looking back and forth at the crowd and pausing while people took pictures. Hee hee!

By the time you read this, I will have less than 2 weeks left here in San Francisco. What a ride this has been so far! WHEE!

Thursday was a little bit better. I got to take the morning and afternoon off and sleep in and roam the city a little. I went to have a manicure (which was crappy - but what do you expect for $8??). Of course most of the people having manicures were men. Only in San Francisco. ;) One of the guys asked me where I was from and what I was doing there. I answered Boston and that I was an opera singer... that is when it hit me. Now, I really am an opera singer. Sure, I've said that before, but it didn't really hold such a special meaning before. I wasn't doing as much as I am now. What a great feeling. It makes me smile everytime I think about it. 

So, after my brief conversation about what I was doing there, I asked the gentleman where there was a good place to get a sandwich around here. I've been able to explore the city a great deal, but not as much in my immediate area. There are restaurants everywhere around where I am, but nothing like a deli. So, he told me to walk a couple of blocks over which is where I found Miller's East Coast Delicatessen. YUMMEH!!! Their sandwiches are a lot like Carnegie Deli in New York. Not as amazing, or as huge. But quite good! If ever any of you come out here, come on out to Clay & Polk to find the deli! :) 

Thursday night's rehearsal was ok. We're all getting a little weary. But the chorus was given a special nod. Everyone was asked to stand and give us applause for all of our hard work. It was very kind of them. We all felt a little better.

Today was a good day! I woke up early in the am as I had to go to my coaching for Silla. What a GORGEOUS day!! Not a cloud in the sky, which is so rare around here. lol. It was warm and lovely. I got to the school early because I needed to warm up and attempt to get all of this Silla stuff under my belt. I felt ok with it, but I wanted to be a little more confident in some of the ornamentations. When I got there, I found out that I was supposed to sing in Aria Class. Oops. I didn't know. I only had 1/2 an hour from when Aria Class started to when I went to my coaching, so I asked one of the girls if she had a Soprano Rep book with her. She only had one aria in her book that I knew. So I sang "The Black Swan" from "The Medium". One of my favorite arias. But seeing as how I am still a little sick and it was 10:00am, it wasn't my best work. But, I did get some great insight. Patricia Craig, who is from New England Conservatory (NEC) in Boston was giving the class. She gave me some suggestions about breath support. And then she asked me about my background, which I told her. She then asked me if they allowed me to sing big repertoire @ Hartt. Which basically means, did they allow me to sing repertoire that was written for big voices. Which they didn't. She then went on to describe to the class how if they reign in a big voice when it is younger, it makes it very difficult to make it big again. Which is exactly what I have been working towards for the past few years. It has been a long rough road, but my teacher is wonderful and has helped me through it slowly, and the right way. She asked me who my teacher was and she replied that I was in excellent hands. All very true and well observed. 

I ran to my coaching right after. It was fantastic! My conductor hasn't heard me sing the aria yet and she had written the great ornamentations for me without hearing what I could do. But I told her that I would try anything, just couldn't guarantee that it would work. But she loved my attitude. She said that they could use more people like me in the cast. With all of the drama going on, people haven't exactly been cooperative. So, I sang it, and she got sooo excited! She said she couldn't understand why they hadn't given me a bigger role when I am so good at Handel. She said she really wished that they had given me the role of one of the sopranos. I was flabbergasted! (oh - good word!) I was truly shocked to hear that. But ecstatic at the same time. 

I had Silla rehearsal the whole rest of the day. I did a lot of staging for my silent role. There is a lot of running around required. Definitely got my work out for the day! The director then worked with me on the staging for my aria. We had to change it a little as my ornamentations are different from Nick's and the rythm's didn't really work with the footwork. So, we worked and worked and worked on it until I finally got comfortable with both the aria and the staging. Thank god I had that extra time because tech week starts on Monday! EEK! 

It was a really good day. Cosi dress rehearsal also went well and we actually got out a little earlier than planned - yay! Have I mentioned one of the tenors in Cosi? I am NOT a fan of tenors. Don't know why, I'm just not a fan of their voice type, but Eli - he can make anyone melt with his voice. He is simply fantastic and was born for stardom. I mean, he has it written all over him. And is also quite humble and the sweetest person you could meet. I wish you could hear him. For all of you opera buffs out there who are reading this, remember the name Eleazar Rodriguez - you WILL hear of him someday! He is wonderful!

Anyway, here it is. The night before opening for Cosi and I am still happy. I keep thinking that one of these days I am going to just say - I hate this and want to go home. But those feelings never come, no matter what - I love this. And I know that this is what I am meant to do.

I had forgotten how it can be in the "real world" or in this case. The real singing world. It is late Wednesday night and I have just come back from a crappy rehearsal for Cosi fan Tutte. I am in the chorus for this opera, which is good because it keeps you humble. At least that is what I keep telling myself. The chorus also serves as the set crew. So we are in full costume and running around doing set changes. Some while we are singing. It sucks. I don't like it, none of us do. We've been able to be silly and laugh things off, but today, we were treated like crap, and we were all crabby for the remainder of the 4 hours of rehearsal. Blargh! 

This only came after I had a rough rehearsal for Silla. I haven't sung the full aria with accompaniment or anything since the day after I heard it for the first time. And I didn't have much time to run it. So, needless to say, it doesn't sound that great. It downright sucked. And with me being sick and never having done the staging, made it suck even more! They were very nice and understanding, but that is only going to last this one time, next week is tech week and we have to have it perfect. I just felt bad and unprofessional. They weren't rude or demeaning about it at all, but I am hard on myself and felt bad about the whole situation. But that is ok. I needed a kick in the butt to make sure that I learn what I need to and practice. The main issue is that my ornamentations for the second part of the aria are different than Nick's, and not in the same rythm. That presents a huuuge challenge. I can do it, just really have to work on it as much as possible. Which I will!

Monday my mom was here for her last day. We went to Fisherman's Wharf where we found Lark in The Morning. It is a huge musical instrument store here in Frisco. We took a cable car from my mom's place and went all the way down to the wharf. I bought a concertina for our ren faire groups. I am psyched! Always wanted to learn to play one. And it wasn't that expensive. I was planning to spend much more. So that was great! After playing with every instrument in the store, mom & I went for lunch @ Boudin's Bakery. They are famous for their sourdough. Their New England Clam Chowder in a bread bowl is the most delicious thing I have EVER had. I had one when I first got here and have been raving about them to my mom ever since. We both giggled at the irony of eating new england clam chowder while in california. ;) We also hit this amazing pirate store. Had EVERYTHING piratical that you can think of. Super pricey though, so we didn't get that much. The ROE girls would lurrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrvvvvvvvveee this store!!!

It was getting close to time for my mom to go. So we went back to Union Square and hit Macy's on the way to the hotel. I went a little crazy. Their large designer departments are RIDICULOUS! I got some awesome clothes. Whee! Yes, I know, you are all saying, Gils, the last thing you need is clothes. And yes, you are right. But we don't have this kind of stuff @ home. So that is a good reason right? *wink wink*

By the time my mom had to leave I was kind of regretting that I did all of that walking in the wind and cold. It wasn't that bad, but I was just getting really sick and I probably shouldn't have gone anywhere that day. But that is ok. I am doing all right and I think I am finally getting over this damn cold! Echinacea and vitamin c are my bestest friends!

My first rehearsal at the Conservatory here was on Monday night after my mom left. Thankfully, it is only a few stops away on a bus for me. So not a bad trip at all! The first rehearsal was ok. We were all still bright eyed and bushy tailed. But as the days past, we are getting a little more annoyed and exhausted by everything that we have to do. Tuesday we had a 10 hour rehearsal. And that was after Nick & I had to go to Silla first. That was a looooooong day. We were all pretty bored and bummed by the end of the night. 10 hours of rehearsal is kinda crazy. But thankfully, we had an hour and 1/2 for dinner when we were replenished by the lcal crepe house. :) Yummy crepes with nutella!!!

Well, other than being tired and a little bummed/pissed off. There is nothing much else to report. I almost wanted to go home today. Just cuz I feel like I have been doing this same opera for like a year! I'm not kidding. I feel like we have done it over and over and over. And we really haven't. But there is only so many times that we can rehearse things before we all get cranky, ya know? It'll be over soon and the next level of hell will start.

I'm still hapy though. I love this program and the people in it. I am so blessed to have this opportunity. And I am taking every chance that I have to get what I can out of it. So far so good. I only have a few more weeks left and they are going to just fly by.

Hope all is well with all of you. I can't wait to hear the stories that you all have to tell when I get back. Hugs until then!

Has it been that long since I have updated??

I believe the last time that I updated was...Monday?? Yah, that is about right. Let me see if I can remember what has happened since then... Tuesday wasn't super exciting. I had a series of rehearsals, including a last minute call for Silla rehearsal. This new opera is making my schedule a mess, but that is ok. I wasn't planning on going in until about 3:00 that afternoon because my first rehearsal wasn't until then and I wanted to sleep as late as possible. But I got a call at about 1:00pm (while getting ready to get lunch) saying... Ummm...Gils? Yah. I have some bad news for you. What? Did you know that you have rehearsal right now? Umm...no, I do? Yes. Ok, well I will be there in 25-30 minutes then. Nick (the other person paying God - yes that is the character that I play!) didn't know that he had rehearsal either, and he comes in from Oakland, so he was late too. But the director was, thankfully, very understanding. It seems as though as well as playing a major role on 2 nights, I will be playing a silent (but extremely huge) role of a servant the other 2 nights. I love silent roles, they save your voice and often times you are on stage more with a silent role than you are with a singing role. It is great! Good deal for me!

Tuesday night we had our first staging rehearsal for Cosi. Oh the fun! It was fantastic! A lot of us that are in it together have also been in classes and other rehearsals together, so we are all buddy-buddy. And seeing as how it was night and we were all kind sleepy, we started getting slap happy and were giggling up a storm. Not so much to be distracting to the others, but still enough to be crazy. We are all looking forward to the performances as we all get to spend lots of extra time just being silly.

There was also a party being thrown that same night by one of the girls who lives here. She knows a lot of local singers and her roomie is the accompanist for a very very prestigious young artist program here, so everyone was planning to go over to her house as it was the only night when we could all sleep in the next day. I wasn't planning on going but I was persuaded by a few of the folks and almost pushed into the car. ha ha! On the way there I had another San Francisco moment. We were driving down Fillmore Street and all of a sudden we couldn't see over the car. MAJOR drop down the hill. It was scary as hell. We were all like EEEK! lol. It was a priceless moment. So, we got to the party at about 10:00 and nobody from our program had shown up yet. So, we made ourselves at home and began to "take over" the party. :) Would all expect any less? Slowly, the rest of the troops came trickling in. It was an ok party. I wasn't feeling too festive because I didn't feel dressed for a party. I didn't look atrocious, but I wasn't in my "party clothes" so I felt out of my element a little. And can I just say that I still find it really really hard to be comfortable hanging out and partying with my conductors or directors??? I mean, no, I don't drink or anything, so maybe that makes it weirder. But I just can't get used to the idea! It is soooo strange! They jus saunter on up to you and strike up a normal conversation when earlier that same day, they were yelling at you for something. Just teaches you that you can't take anything personally, I guess. I ended up leaving the party a little earlier than most. Fun, but just wasn't feeling it. Thankfully, it was pretty close to where I am staying.

Got to sleep in on July 4th! That gave me 2 days of sleeping in. Thank god! Had to stock up on sleep seeing as how my schedule was going to get crazier and longer, especially over the weekend. I decided that I wanted to catch a movie. Unfortunately, Pirates 3 wasn't playing nearby. WAH!! Still haven't seen it, just never got a chance what with the performing and the packing and the working... anyway, I saw "Ratatuoille" instead. It was very cute. But in my opinion, totally over-hyped!! I found it funny and cute, but personally, I prefer "Cars". It definitely had it's moments. Especially since it was based in Paris. Loved the moments when I could be like "OH! I know where that is - I was there!" Of course it is Pixar so everything in it was witty and wonderful. :)

After the movie, I had a few hours to practice my new role until I had a party to go to. A couple of BASOTI folks are sub-letting an apartment in the Richmond District, which is definitely not the prettiest part of town. It isn't unsafe, just not much to look at. So, I went out there and when I had to switch buses, I had to wait for 45 minutes! That SUUUUUUUCKED! It wasn't super cold that day, but it was really really really windy. I got a little worried for a while, the buses usually run pretty much on time here. I was suprised how good they were. But not on this day. I hate holiday bus schedules, they say it is going to be one thing, but you actually have to add about 20-30 minutes on to the scedule. BLAH! When I finally got on, I had to get off a little earlier cuz of an accident up ahead that was blocking the road, so I had to walk many blocks, uphill. Thought it would be closer, it wasn't. Eh, no big, I don't really mind walking. When I finally got there, not many people were there. And the vibe was a little strange. I got the feeling that there would be drama somewhere very soon. It wasn't bad. Not really my scene. I stayed for a few hours and socialized. But ultimately, I ended up leaving when people got more intoxiacted. I'm not too keen on being around drunk people. Which I had to endure the whole way home! BLECH! I had to wait forever, again for another bus and it was so packed full of drunked crazy people, that I got off and just started walking. lol. Just didn't want to deal with it. Though, I must say, I looked fabulous! ;)

When I finally got dropped off at the top of my hill, I was just in time to watch the fireworks over by Firsherman's Wharf. It was a great view! Just a block away from where I'm staying! The fireworks show was great. I am such a kid. I love fireworks! Though, let me tell you, no one does the 4th of July like Boston!! We are famous for our show @ the Esplanade and our fireworks. And for good reason! Go Boston! ;)

Thursday I got to sleep again! 3 days in a row?? WHEE! My mom was also expected to fly in @ about 12:45pm. YAY! As I was walking to my rehearsal, she called and let me know that she got here safely. Our family friend Vito was kindly picking her up and taking her around the city for a few days with his wife. I told her that if I could get out early enough that night, I would try to come and see her. Luckily, my rehearsal ended early and I got to spend about 45 minutes with her before I had to go to dress rehearsal for my first peformance of The Tempest on Friday night. Unfortunatley, I got out super late and though my mom came over for a bit to see my apartment, she was exhausted from jet laggishness and couldn't stay long. So, no hanging out with mom until Saturday. Of course it was just my luck that it got much colder than expected that night and I had to wait for a few buses as I thought I would be going to my mom's hotel. So, standing there in the freezing wind. Not a good idea.

The next morning, I woke up, my throat was KILLING me. OWIE! I was going to go to my "Business of Singing" class, but I could not drag my butt out of bed. I felt awful. Luckily, I only had one other rehearsal that day and my call for the performance that night wasn't until 7:00. So, I called in and just stayed in bed all day. Thankfully, my throat pain was high enough that it didn't effect my voice. I swear, there is someone up there looking over me. I would have been SCREWED! I took echinacea all day long and vitamins and got soup and tea as much as I could. It sucks not having a microwave or something to heat food in/on. That would've been helpful in this situation. I sucked it up and went to the show. It went very very well. And I was so glad! The problem, I had another dress rehearsal then next morning. Ugh! 

Who the hell thought of forcing us to be warmed up, in makeup and costume by 9:30am needs to be shot! My cold had fully set upon me and my throat was still hurting. I was in a PANIC. So, I vocalized a little before I left my room to go to dress rehearsal. It didn't sound too bad and the pain was still sitting pretty high. The first scene was actually really good. My conductor was hard on us, once again, and even though I was sick as a dog, he made us go through some things outside in the cold. Thanks John! I was not happy. The rest of the rehearsal also went very well. I was really surprised that I could get anything out at all! By the time we were done, it was 1:00pm and I was dizzy. I found my director for Silla and asked Nick if he could stand in and just tell me what I missed later. It is a blessing to have double casting! Nick & Meghan spent about 10 minutes convincing me that I needed to eat something to feel better. So they dragged me to everyone's favorite local pizza place - Pizza Orgasmica. Yes, that is the name of the place. LOL! And yes, the pizza is that good. They specialize in all kinds of different flavored gourmet pizzas. Yummeh! 

I was released from my captors after lunch and allowed to go home to see my mom. ;) She came over to my apartment because it was freezing and I just didn't want to make the trek to her hotel. I was able to just hang out with my mom and do nothing all day. It was nice actually. But kinda weird. She kept saying that it was strange being there. Our family friends had to go back home (not far from here) on Saturday morning. They were so sweet to take her around and show her things. She got to go to Fisherman's Wharf & Pier 39. They also took her to Sausalito and she shopped in Union Square. So she was glad to have a little down time. 

Today (sunday) was my 2nd performance. And thanks to Bailey's Irish Cream which I sipped several times yesterday, my sore throat was gone. YEARS of blowing my voice out @ Ren Faires has taught me that Bailey's is my best friend! Not a ton, just a sip or two. It is great! Thank you Bailey's! LOL! I should do commercials for them. So, with a horrible cold left over, I got up, got ready and went to the show. Forgot my camera - oops, went back to the room. Then about 3/4of the way there, I realized that I had forgotten one of my costume pieces. CRAP!!! So, I hopped on another bus (after almost getting hit by a car while crossing the street) and went back to grab it. I figured, hey I will try to get a cab and if I can't I will take the bus again. Whichever comes first. Got the bus. And got there with time to spare. I was doing my makeup on the bus on the way to try and save time. I kept getting all of these looks from the passengers. One woman looked over at me and said "why are you putting so much make up on?" Of course, I had to be polite and tell her that it was stage makeup. Ah, the stories one hears on a bus. he he.

However, it seems that everyone who was in the program was trying to warm up at the same time, so I was running around trying to find a place to warm up. Just ended up doing it in the makeup room in front of everyone. Hey, I don't care, I need to warm up, I'm in the first scene. That was interesting to say the least. When you warm up, you don't exactly sound pretty at first. But it taught me not to worry about it. When you have to get ready, you have to get ready! It was really weird though. Somehow I managed to sing everything well. It wasn't bad at all. I was pleasantly surprised. Getting enough breath support when you are completely congested isn't easy. But you have to get through it as best you can. We got lots of laughs and lots of applause and everyone enjoyed the performance. The last scene was the worst for me. My makeup was not agreeing with me at all. It was kind of painted on, and my eyes had the worst reaction to it. I started tearing up and then it started stinging. Owie. And then I was so teary that I just couldn't see. So, I went on like nothing was happening. My eyes were watering so badly that I looked like I was crying. My colleagues were all freaking out afterwards cuz they thought I was actually crying. lol. I wasn't. The makeup didn't get all over my face, which I was worried about. It didn't run all over the place. If it had, I would've looked like death. Thank god it didn't!!

My mom took me to a 3 star restaurant to celebrate. We had delicious food from famous chef Michael Mina. Not the best food ever. But it was fun to see how people who live the high life eat. It was like a movie. :) 

Ok, so now I think we are all caught up. Tomorrow is my mom's last day here and we are going to Lark in the morning. It is a very famous music store that has thousands of different instruments. I want a concertina for the ren faire stuff. Yes, I am a dork. But I love it. :)

Oh, and one more story to tell. Something that I will never forget - my rehearsals for The Tempest. Our conductor had the best accent ever! And at one part, the goddeses (I was Juno - the highest of all godesses") had to sing "Honor, Riches, marriage blessing". He used to tell us how to say riches in rythm. But when he said it with the accent, it sounded like "Reeches" We love him! He was great. Could be very serious but very fun at the same time. And Hector Correa was the best director that I have ever worked with! I will never forget them and am so thankful that I got to work with them!!

Yesterday was Friday. It was a rough day. We staged the rest of Merry Wives first thing in the am. It was a little crazy. The conductor wants us to sing a particularly difficult part in another way and it is already challenging enough without it being changed. So we struggled with it and everyone got a little exasperated. I got more exasperated than anyone else really, but it was just hard. Everyone gets a little annoyed with themselves in the entertainment world, it is normal. I just hate it when things don't go all that well. But, it'll be fine. :)

I went to get fitted for the rest of my costumes right after with some of the girls. I of course was recruited to tie some people into corsets and the like. Hey, 7 years of Ren Faires gives me major corset-tying experience! I am a pro. :) The costumer is ecstatic to have a fellow rennie around. She does some of the faires around here sometimes. She is a doll, I really liked her. And luckily, the pieces that I brought with me to wear work really well with her designs, so I get to use some of my own stuff - whee!

My second rehearsal of the day felt kind of endless, but we got a ton done. It was very prodcutive. I am singing in an Aria Afternoon tomorrow and the piece I am doing is rare and difficult. Luckily, the pianist for the rehearsal I had is also the one playing for me tomorrow, so we got to run it a few times. THANK GOD. I was a little nervous about it. Now I am at ease. :)

Thankfully, that was the last rehearsal of the day, so I got to go home for a bit and try to rest myself. All of these rehearsals are increasing in numbers and length, so my exhaustified meter is getting higher. But I am still loving this!! I had a great moment in San Francisco yesterday when I was on the bus. On my side of the hill it was bright and sunny and on the other, the fog was starting to blow in. And as I was looking down one side of the hill, I could see the fog blowing in over the sunny part of the lowest part of the hill. It was sooooo amazingly cool to watch. I almost wished that I had gotten off the bus and just stood there to watch the fog blow in. It was like a movie where the fog rolls in slowly. Awesome. Yes, I know I am a sappy weirdo - ;) but I really enjoyed watching it. It was like a moment of relaxation before a night of german art songs. lol.

So, I went to the "Liederabend" which taken literally means - Songs Night in German. :) It is a night where everyone sings German (or other language) art songs. It was actually lovely. Some of the pieces were not appealing at all, but most of them were very nice. During the intermission, Sylvia approached me and asked me for a moment of my time. I freaked! I thought that I had done something wrong! OH CRAP! So, I followed her preparing myself to hear something awful, and was surprised when she asked if I learn quickly. I said, absolutely, I pride myself on being a quick study. She said, oh good! There is a role available in Silla, would you like it? I said, sure, I would love to do the role. So she told me a little about it and asked me to meet her after the concert ended. EEK!  So, I met with her and we went to get a score from the office, they didn't have any left, so I had to wait until today for a copy. It was 9:30 at night, don't think I would've really had a chance to look at it anyway considering I can't sight read for anything and I don't play piano well. Not to mention, I don't have a keyboard or anything with me! 

I was asked to join many of my fellow colleagues to a local haunt that they all go to after a performance. It was crazy. I ended up having a drink with one of my conductors - weird! But still fun. A lot of the people I didn't really know yet as they aren't in anything that I am doing, but most of them remember me from all of my crazy energy from the first day and from my sneezing at the pants role master class the other night. ;) So, I was a big hit. It was actually really fun. It is great to be in a position where no one has any preconceived notions of you and can form their own opinions. And it is nice to be accepted into a group with similar lives. So many of my friends don't really understand the whole performing thing. And admittedly, it is hard to understand. But these people are all in the same positions and totally get the kind of life that we are asked to lead. It was also interesting to hear some of their stories and great to just unwind a little bit. :) I didn't stay too long, I wanted to head back to my room cuz it takes the bus a little longer at night.

Had an interesting experience on the bus. I swear some day I am going to write a book about my bus experiences. This guy comes onthe bus and keeps yelling (to an invisible person) I'm a veteran! I'm gonna call em! You betcha! You betcha! I'm gonna call em! LOL. I swear, this city has more crazy people than anywhere else! And then this morning, this woman on my bus on the way to rehearsal was telling everyone where they need to stand and how to sit and how we have to respect the older people on the bus. It was completely unecessary and just plain annoying. People were starting to get pissed off with her. 

So, I thought that in a few days, I would be called into rehearsal after I learned the role a little more. BOY was I wrong. I got a call at about 10:00 this morning. I was still sleeping and had not planned to wake up until about 10:45-11:00. But no, I got a call from Miriam asking me if I could come in for a staging rehearsal this morning. Ummm..ok I said, when is it? It started about 10 minutes ago. Uhhh.... ok, I will get there as soon as I can, I have to take a bus. Thank you! Don't worry, they know that you don't have the music yet and don't let them push you around, ok? Well, that last part wasn't fun to hear. So, I drag myself out of bed, and try to make myself semi-presentable. I managed to get out of the room in about 10-15 minutes and luckily caught a bus right away, so I was able to get there fairly early. I am playing "God" in the opera. Is this a typecasting thing? I am playing the highest of all of the goddesses in The Tempest as well. lol.

I sat in on rehearsal and had to go through the staging myself as well. Now, having never heard any of this music and never hearing of this opera, it was all a little overwhelming. And it is Handel which is super hard! I was supposed to be at another rehearsal from 1-5 and then another in between from 2-3. But I had to go to Silla from 1-2 and then went to the other from 2-3 and then went to the other from 3-5. So in between, I had to find 2 of my directors to talk to them about this schedule and try to listen to the conductor for this new opera and try to take in all of the staging. So, I guess it is normal that my head kind of hurts and I feel a little numb huh? 

The cool thing about this is that this is a big deal to be asked to do this. It means that I have been noticed and they have watched my progress over the past 2 weeks. I am really honored to be given this opportunity. This is also the United States Premiere of this opera. There has never been a public performance of it as well, so it is a really big deal. So, basically, this is pretty amazing and crazy and great at the same time. I am excited. But it is all a little difficult. The role is written in a strange key, so the conductor is re-writing it to fit my voice. It is double cast so I can't learn what the other person is singing. This whole thing is pretty confusing. Not a very good day. I woke up feeling a little crap voice-wise. I was a little strained and my back was sore. I had a class in Alexander Technique in the morning. For those of you who don't know what it is, Alexander Technique is the process of being aware of everything around you and being really in the moment and aware of your body. It is very cool. Hard to contemplate, but very cool. We started with how we stand and how we balance. IT is amazing how if you put weight on certain parts of your lower body, your upper body reacts and your voice reacts as well. The correct way to stand is physically straight all the way up, that way you are all aligned and your voice is open and you are able to breathe and move more freely. The difference is incredible. You had to be very comfortable with yourself and we got to know our fellow class members really really really well. There was a lot of touching going on. Now, before you get the wrong idea - as I know most of you would - ha ha. We had to wake up some of our muscles in our backs and our necks, so a partner had to put pressure on certain parts of your back to wake them up. It was actually really interesting to feel the difference. And what we all think is upright and the correct way to stand is not necessarily correct. We all have a tendency to over arch and lean back and in fact, we have to lean forward a bit to be perfectly aligned. You almost feel like you are going to fall over, but you won't. And the difference in the sound when you sing is so incredible!

Grrrrr....  Not that I found a place to actually get a sweatshirt.

I have to say that so far, I am not a fan of this city. Admittedly, I haven't seen that much of it, but so far, not so good. There is nothing but restaurants and seedy stores and homeless people everywhere. lol. Maybe it is cuz I am cold and tired. Today I am feeling better. So hopefully the jetlag is passing. :) 

I have Alexander Technique today and then I have rehearsal from 7-10 so I am going to go out to Pier 39 and see if I can find somewhere to get some warmer clothes. :)

Thanks for reading!

But so happy. 

I had a great day! I went to brunch downstairs in the hotel and met a girl who was part of the program here. She isn't nice. WHATEVER! Don't need people like that around. Then I went upstairs and got to memorization until I left. The bus is about 7 blocks away. I could've taken a bus to that bus, but I figured I need the exercise and I didn't mind walking. It was a lovely day, a little windy and cool, but not cold. 

Some lady on the bus threatened to kick me with her 86 year old knees. It was so funny! I was just standing there on a packed bus and she was like, my knees are 86 years old but it you come close to them, I will kick you. So naturally I said, lady, you kick me and I will just kick you back and my knees are younger and stronger, so I don't reccomend it! LOL! I am so mean. But is was for NO reason. Just some crazy lady. ha ha! This stuff only happens to me. I'll have to save this story for the tell all. ;)

I get there and have a costume fitting and met one of my old English diction teacher's students. She is a doll and our bdays are exactly 5 days apart. Leos rock... or roar??? hee hee. So, orientation started, we heard many wise words from the multiple directors and all kinds of inspirations and some not so inspiring things when they started talking about the rules. Like punctuality and if you are late, you are in trouble and could get cut. Then about how if you don't know your music - you are screwed and will get cut. So there was mucho amounts of scariness, but I wasn't flinching. So that was a good sign. :) I mean it is naturally expected that you know all of these things in the professional world, but you have to say them cuz there are always a few people in the bunch who just don't get it and don't know the music or deter their colleagues by being late. I met all of the people from my scenes, it was weird as we all ended up congregating in the same place and sitting together not knowing that we were all in the same scenes. Met some really great people who are ALOT like me. ha. AKA - INSANE. Met some Diva attitudes as well, but I don't have to interact with them, so whatever. 

One of the really cool things about this is that there are a ton of people like me, tall, bigger and very cool. ;) Now a days the opera world consists of skinny-minis who are like a size two and blond and adorable. But that wasn't what it was like here, which is sooooo encouraging! I guess they really are more laid-back out here on the west coast. And they still hold to the traditions of the old opera world. Which is nice. I'm writing this at about 10:30 my time and 1am your time so if I'm babbling, sorry!

So, during orientation, we all went around and introduces ourselves and stated what our goals were for our time here. I of course was super bubbly and happy and full of energy and said that my goal was to absorb as much as I possibly could both from my colleagues and from the environment around me as I'm new to the whole west coast thing. I also said that I wanted to meet EVERYONE and get to know EVERYONE to wich everyone laughed. I was well-received. ha! Some people came up to me afterwards and were like - OMG, you are such a ball of energy! We love you. tee hee. My evil plan is working. *wrings hands evilly*

After orientation, we went RIGHT into rehearsals. Well, dinner break first and then rehearsals. I feel like crap today because I do have a litle jet lag. Well, my voice has jet lag. But that is ok, the whole weather/environment/time change is naturally going to affect me and my voice. So, I'm not going to be concerned. I didn't sound like utter crap, but I didn't sound my best. My first rehearsal was for The Merry Wives of Windsor and it went well. One of the sopranos unfortunately didn't have the correct score and memorized the wrong words - oopsie! But they were pretty understanding. I didn't do too badly. After the initial OH MY GOD I'M ACTUALLY DOING THIS nervousness wore off, I was good to go and had some fun. My second rehearsal was for The Magic Flute - loved it! I am such a Mozart girl. And I sang A LOT. But by the end of the night, my voice was getting a little tired. Which is to be expected of course. I'm not exactly in the best shape what with back problems and the like for the past few years. But I know that after a week or so, I will be better. For now, just have to rest (ya right - not with my schedule!) and take it easy when I can.

The schedule is pretty nuts. I have classes from 10-12 in the am, lunch break for 1 hour then rehearsals from 1-5 then dinner then rehearsals for something else from 6-10. So, yah, no rest for the wicked! OF course, you don't always have that schedule, you do always have classes in the am, but sometimes you don't have afternoon/evening rehearsals so you can actually go and explore or rest. Tomorrow I have a class in the am and then thankfully I don't have a class. But that can change at the last minute too. :) 

So, for any of you planning to come and visit me, I cannot guarantee that I will be able to spend A TON of time with you. I can absolutely spend some of the time with you folks, but not all of it and most likely not at night. 

Anyway, I didn't have to take the bus back tonight cuz of one the girls in my scenes is from Berkely and was gracious enough to drive me home as it was on her way. YAY FOR RIDES!! OH! And one more great story... I was asking a question about the audition class and how we were supposed to dress and the director of the program was like - GILIANA we are SO glad to see your smiling face again, I'm so happy that you could join us. LOVE HER! WHEE! I left an impression and in this businnes, I cannot even begin to tell you how important that is!!!

Ok, I am babbling and I need to get some sleep. Until next time. Keep smiling.

......Wait, that doesn't work! How bout - If you're going to San Francisco, be sure to wear some flowers in your hair....

 

Well, there are no flowers in my hair but here I am in San Francisco. I arrived safely yesterday afternoon. Well sort of safely...

 

The flight was fine, little to no turbulence. Yay. It was packed with people, though. The only problem was that my headphone port didn't work and I couldn't watch the in flight tv shows and movie. Well, I watched them, just without sound. Actually, that can be quite amusing. So, I was a good girl and learned my music instead. And the views from the plane were really amazing. The air was clear in most parts of the mid-west so you could see the fields and flatness of the land. At one point, all the fields were round. Interesting, my mind kept wandering to crop circles. lol. Then we flew over the Rockies. WOW! GORGEOUS! They were slightly snow-capped and simply magnificent. I love mountains. I think they are amazing, must be from all of those years of skiing! 

 

Anyway, the rest of the flight was fine. The touchdown to the runway however, SUCKED! It was super bumpy and we hit the run way at sort of an angle, so that was NOT fun. After that everyone was like "Get me off of this plane". Then we all had to wait for about an hour for our luggage. They were having problems with the belt that brought it up to us. Grrr.. After being on the plane for 6 hours, all you want to do is get your stuff and head to wherever it is that you are going. 

 

I grabbed a cab and got to my hotel. It is actually very nice. An old house that has rooms that are like apartments. They have private rooms as well as shared suites. Mu room is like a 3 room apartment. And it is great! I have a large living room with a couch and tv and stuff. Then my bedroom is also large and very nice with 2 huge closets. My bathroom is FABULOUS. They just re-did it and it is great!! I will post pictures later. :) You have to be buzzed in to the hotel. It is very safe, not in the greatest part of town, but not that bad either. But I love it. And they have a lift! I loooove lifts! I think they are the coolest things. I'm not an elevator girl, but lifts rock. It has these guilded doors that you have to pull bak to get on and off. I keep forgetting and waiting for the doors to open - lmao. 

 

It is COLD here people! I had plenty of warning from many people that it gets cold here in the summer, so I am prepared. But geez. Today it was only in the low 50s. They said that it hasn't been that cold at all and it was almost 80 the day before yesterday. Well, good, I'd rather haev like 60s and 70s than 50s. Brrr! There was no sun yesterday either. All fog. But by the end of the day, the fog was burned off a bit and the sun came out. I went exploring a bit. I was so tired from not really sleeping the night before (last minute packing is a bad idea). And was still on Boston time, so I was a little messed up time-wise, but now that I've had a good night's sleep, I feel much better! And the hills here - sheesh! I don't know how some of the cars make it up some of these hills cuz they are soooooo steep! Good thing there isn't snow here or everyone would be screwed!! lol.

 

Today (Sunday) I have orientation and then we dive right into rehearsals. I have 3 rehearsals all going on at the same time... that will work out well, I'm sure. Ah, the performer's life for me. Tomorrow I hope to get to do a bit of exploring as our rehearsals are near Golden Gate Park and such. Still haven't seen the bridge. :) I'm sure that when I do, I will be a dork and take a million pictures. lol. 

 

So, off to breakfast for me. Hope you are all well! I have the wireless situation figured out now, so I will update when next I have a moment!

 

Thanks for reading!
